metatags.subject: Discusses laws and policies that address the issue of substance use by parents. One major area of concern is responding to the care and treatment needs of substance-exposed infants. title: Contrasting Early German and English Child Welfare Legislation for ...
htmlTitle: Contrasting Early German and English Child Welfare Legislation for ...
snippet: 17 hours ago ... This article presents the roots of the child welfare system of one large, early-industrialised European country, Germany, with reference to another,. England.
htmlSnippet: 17 hours ago ... This article presents the roots of the child welfare system of one large, early-industrialised European country, Germany, with reference to another,. England.

metatags.creator: Servigistics Arbortext Advanced Print Publisher 11.1.4667/W
metatags.author: Magnus Frampton
metatags.subject: Doi: 10.1093/bjsw/bcae048 The British Journal of Social Work, 00, 00, 2024 Publication Date: 13/04/2024 Abstract National child welfare systems are often unalike in their orientation, and can be understood comparatively. Influenced by the principles of historical institutionalism, this article contrasts early German and English child welfare legislation. The first national German system was based on a statute rarely discussed in English-language social work histories: the Reichsgesetz für Jugendwohlfahrt (National Youth Welfare Act). This legislation came into force in 1924, systematically uniting comprehensive services related to childhood. The law is examined in the context of its contemporaneous cultural, political and academic discourses, and contrasted with English developments. The intentions of the legislation-drafters, as well as ideas specific to German-language discourses such as Erziehung (child-raising) and Verwahrlosung (presenting the effects of abuse/neglect) are investigated to cautiously
metatags.title: The ‘Right to an Upbringing’—Contrasting Early German and English Child Welfare Legislation for a Case Study in Comparative Social Work History
